elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">TGA diagram of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (under nitrogen atmosphere). The first mass loss (62.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) corresponds to 12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and the second one (202.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) to 6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Dashed line represents the first derivative.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  TGA diagram of compound 2 (under nitrogen atmosphere). The first mass loss (62.0°C) corresponds to 12H2O, and the second one (202.4°C) to 6H2O. Dashed line represents the first derivative.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">View of the structure of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] with atom labelling. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at 30% probability level, and all hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  View of the structure of [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6] with atom labelling. Thermal ellipsoids are drawn at 30% probability level, and all hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Packing view of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] showing the 3D columnar structure generated and the channels along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis. H atoms and crystallization water molecules are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Packing view of [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6] showing the 3D columnar structure generated and the channels along the crystallographic c axis. H atoms and crystallization water molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Thermal variation of the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (a), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (b), <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (c) and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (d): (o) experimental data; (- - -) best fit curve considering no magnetic interaction; (—-) best fit curve considering antiferromagnetic interaction (see text).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Thermal variation of the χ M T product for compounds 1 (a), 2 (b), 3 (c) and 4 (d): (o) experimental data; (- - -) best fit curve considering no magnetic interaction; (--) best fit curve considering antiferromagnetic interaction (see text).

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig5">
<ce:label>Fig. 5</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Species distribution diagram for the Ni(II)-oda (a), Pb(II)-oda (b), and Sm(III)-oda systems (c). In all cases, [oda]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>30 mM, [M]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10 mM, <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>25.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCl. Charges of the species are omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr5"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 5  Species distribution diagram for the Ni(II)-oda (a), Pb(II)-oda (b), and Sm(III)-oda systems (c). In all cases, [oda]=30 mM, [M]=10 mM, T =25.0°C, and I =0.5M Me4NCl. Charges of the species are omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig6">
<ce:label>Fig. 6</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Species distribution diagram for the Sm–Cu–oda system. In both figures, [Sm]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2mM, [Cu]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3mM, [oda]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6mM, <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>25.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCl.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr6"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 6  Species distribution diagram for the Sm-Cu-oda system. In both figures, [Sm]=2mM, [Cu]=3mM, [oda]=6mM, T =25.0°C, and I =0.5M Me4NCl.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>rH<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>. β<ce:inf loc="post">qpr</ce:inf> (M-oda species) corresponds to the equilibria: qM<ce:sup loc="post">3+/2+</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>pL<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>rH<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (r<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0); qM<ce:sup loc="post">3+/2+</ce:sup>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Heterometallic compounds containing Sm(III), bivalent cations M (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ca, Mg), and 2′,2′-oxydiacetate (oda) as connecting ligand have been prepared and characterized. The complexes can be formulated as [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>xH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The structure of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] shows the presence of the Sm(III) coordinated by six carboxy and three ether oxygen atoms, and the Cu(II) cation bonded to four carboxy oxygens and two molecules of water. An open 3D framework is observed, containing large hexagonal channels. At room temperature, the polynuclear complexes behave as built by magnetically isolated paramagnetic ions, but at low temperatures, very weak antiferromagnetic interactions M – M are predominant. The chemical systems were also investigated in solution (25.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCl) by potentiometry. The same kind of polynuclear species have been found.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Heterometallic compounds containing Sm(III), bivalent cations M (M=Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ca, Mg), and 2',2'-oxydiacetate (oda) as connecting ligand have been prepared and characterized. The complexes can be formulated as [Sm2M3(oda)6]⋅xH2O. The structure of [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6] shows the presence of the Sm(III) coordinated by six carboxy and three ether oxygen atoms, and the Cu(II) cation bonded to four carboxy oxygens and two molecules of water. An open 3D framework is observed, containing large hexagonal channels. At room temperature, the polynuclear complexes behave as built by magnetically isolated paramagnetic ions, but at low temperatures, very weak antiferromagnetic interactions M - M are predominant. The chemical systems were also investigated in solution (25.0°C, I =0.5M Me4NCl) by potentiometry. The same kind of polynuclear species have been found.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">During the last ten years, heterobimetallic complexes containing Cu(II) and lanthanide ions (Ln) bridged by carboxylic acids have been reported and studied . Other examples, though scarce, include analogous complexes containing other metals instead of copper . In such compounds, metal ions are connected by carboxylato bridges resulting in different structural architectures, from discrete bimetallic complexes to extended 3D arrays. Besides the fascinating structural diversities, these compounds show potential applications in different fields. They are appropriate models to study the nature of magnetic interactions between lanthanides and d-transition metal ions, and they could be useful materials in separation, catalysis, gas storage and molecular recognition . A very recent and excellent review accounts for this kind of polynuclear complexes .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

During the last ten years, heterobimetallic complexes containing Cu(II) and lanthanide ions (Ln) bridged by carboxylic acids have been reported and studied . Other examples, though scarce, include analogous complexes containing other metals instead of copper . In such compounds, metal ions are connected by carboxylato bridges resulting in different structural architectures, from discrete bimetallic complexes to extended 3D arrays. Besides the fascinating structural diversities, these compounds show potential applications in different fields. They are appropriate models to study the nature of magnetic interactions between lanthanides and d-transition metal ions, and they could be useful materials in separation, catalysis, gas storage and molecular recognition . A very recent and excellent review accounts for this kind of polynuclear complexes .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Among the potential carboxylato bridges, oda (2,2′-oxydiacetate) has proved to bridge Ln(III) and Cu(II) with the formation of very interesting structures . In these structures, the Ln metal ion is nine coordinated, being surrounded by nine oxygen atoms from three oda ligands. Copper atoms are six coordinated by six oxygen atoms, four from [Ln(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] units (through a μ-COO bridge), and two from water molecules. The structures [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Gd, Nd), [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Dy, Ho, Y, Gd, Eu, Nd, Pr), [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Nd, Er, Yb), and [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La, Ce) have been reported. Analogous complexes with Sm, Tb, Tm and Lu have not been studied. The most interesting point in the structures is the formation of a 3D network containing large hexagonal channels of nearly 6Å diameter. The channels contain the lattice water molecules. This type of structures is very interesting for many applications. As catalysts for example, they can provide appropriate binding and activation of the reacting molecules, as well as stabilization of reaction intermediates and transition states.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Among the potential carboxylato bridges, oda (2,2'-oxydiacetate) has proved to bridge Ln(III) and Cu(II) with the formation of very interesting structures . In these structures, the Ln metal ion is nine coordinated, being surrounded by nine oxygen atoms from three oda ligands. Copper atoms are six coordinated by six oxygen atoms, four from [Ln(oda)3] units (through a μ-COO bridge), and two from water molecules. The structures [Ln2Cu3(oda)6]⋅3H2O (Ln=Gd, Nd), [Ln2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅12H2O (Ln=Dy, Ho, Y, Gd, Eu, Nd, Pr), [Ln2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6] (Ln=Nd, Er, Yb), and [Ln2Cu3(μ2-H2O)(oda)6(H2O)3]⋅3H2O (Ln=La, Ce) have been reported. Analogous complexes with Sm, Tb, Tm and Lu have not been studied. The most interesting point in the structures is the formation of a 3D network containing large hexagonal channels of nearly 6Å diameter. The channels contain the lattice water molecules. This type of structures is very interesting for many applications. As catalysts for example, they can provide appropriate binding and activation of the reacting molecules, as well as stabilization of reaction intermediates and transition states.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Up to now, the studies on these heteropolynuclear complexes have been mostly focused on lanthanide-copper compounds at solid state. No reports can be found on the possibility to prepare analogous complexes with other M(II) transition metals. Moreover, it would be very interesting to know if such polynuclear species can also exist in aqueous solution. If so, the complexes would be potential homogeneous catalysts for many processes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Up to now, the studies on these heteropolynuclear complexes have been mostly focused on lanthanide-copper compounds at solid state. No reports can be found on the possibility to prepare analogous complexes with other M(II) transition metals. Moreover, it would be very interesting to know if such polynuclear species can also exist in aqueous solution. If so, the complexes would be potential homogeneous catalysts for many processes.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">With this in mind, we decided to investigate the Sm(III)-oda-M(II) (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cu, Mn, Ni, Fe, Co, Ca, Zn, Cd, Be, Mg, Pb) and Sm(III)-oda-VO<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> systems, both at solid state and in solution. Samarium has not been previously studied, neither in solution nor at solid state, and provides a new example to further investigate this interesting series. Chemical speciation of these systems at 25.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCl is reported for the first time. In addition, a few systems containing M′(III) cations (M′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Fe, Al) are included in this work. We also report susceptibility measurements of the magnetically relevant heteropolynuclear species.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With this in mind, we decided to investigate the Sm(III)-oda-M(II) (M=Cu, Mn, Ni, Fe, Co, Ca, Zn, Cd, Be, Mg, Pb) and Sm(III)-oda-VO2+ systems, both at solid state and in solution. Samarium has not been previously studied, neither in solution nor at solid state, and provides a new example to further investigate this interesting series. Chemical speciation of these systems at 25.0°C, I =0.5M Me4NCl is reported for the first time. In addition, a few systems containing M'(III) cations (M'=Fe, Al) are included in this work. We also report susceptibility measurements of the magnetically relevant heteropolynuclear species.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All common laboratory chemicals were reagent grade, purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Sm(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O, SmCl3 ⋅6H2O, BeSO4 ⋅4H2O, CaCl2 ⋅2H2O, MgCl2 ⋅6H2O, MnCl2 ⋅4H2O, NiCl2 ⋅6H2O, ZnCl2, CdCl2 ⋅2.5H2O, CoCl2 ⋅6H2O, Cu(NO3)2 ⋅3H2O, CuCl2 ⋅2H2O, Pb(NO3)2, FeSO4 ⋅7H2O, FeCl3 ⋅6H2O, Al(NO3)3 ⋅9H2O, and an aqueous commercial 48% solution of VOCl2, were used as metal sources. 2,2'-Oxydiacetic acid solutions were prepared by weighing the Fluka reagent.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The infrared spectra, as KBr pellets, were obtained from a Bomen MB 102 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis (C, H) was performed on a Carlo Erba EA 1108 instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument with a TA 50I interface, using a platinum cell and nitrogen atmosphere. Experimental conditions were 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> temperature ramp rate and 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> nitrogen flow rate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra, as KBr pellets, were obtained from a Bomen MB 102 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis (C, H) was performed on a Carlo Erba EA 1108 instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument with a TA 50I interface, using a platinum cell and nitrogen atmosphere. Experimental conditions were 0.5°Cmin-1 temperature ramp rate and 50mLmin-1 nitrogen flow rate.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the complexes

Synthesis of [Sm2 Cu3(oda)6]⋅18H2O(1)

Cu(NO3)2 ⋅3H2O (0.36g, 1.5mmol) and Sm(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.0mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2'-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40g, 3.0mmol) was dissolved in another 10mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear blue solution was obtained. After a few minutes a microcrystalline pale blue solid was obtained, and separated by filtration, washed with water (3×2mL), and dried with acetone (2×2mL) and diethylether (3×2mL). The mother liquour was allowed to evaporate slowly for 4-5 days in order to obtain suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction. Yield 60-70%. Anal. Calc. for C24H60O48Cu3Sm2: C, 17.9; H, 3.8. Found: C, 19.8; H, 4.2%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1605, 1439, and 1124cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 19.6% in the range 50-100°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.2%. Decomposition point, 216°C.

Both solutions were mixed, and a clear green solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for 4–5 days. A pale green solid was filtered, washed with water (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and dried with acetone (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and diethylether (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Found: C, 18.0; H, 4.0%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1618, 1438, and 1125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.4% in the range 50–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.3%. Decomposition point, 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Sm2Ni3 (oda)6]⋅18H2O(2)

Ni(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.5mmol) and Sm(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.0mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2'-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40g, 3.0mmol) was dissolved in another 10mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear green solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for 4-5 days. A pale green solid was filtered, washed with water (3×2mL), and dried with acetone (2×2mL) and diethylether (3×2mL). Yield 35-40%. Anal. Calc. for C24H60O48Ni3Sm2: C, 18.1; H, 3.8. Found: C, 18.0; H, 4.0%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1618, 1438, and 1125cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.4% in the range 50-220°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.3%. Decomposition point, 296°C.

<ce:section-title>X-Ray data collection and refinement</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray data collection for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed at room temperature (293(2) K) with a Xcalibur diffractometer (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)) equipped with a Sapphire-II CCD camera as an area detector. The data reduction was done with the CrysAlis RED program . Neither absorption nor extinction corrections were applied. Relevant crystallographic data are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. The structure was solved by direct methods locating most non-hydrogen atoms. It was completed by successive difference Fourier maps. Refinement was anisotropic for non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were calculated at idealized positions with fixed distances, and refined with isotropic displacement parameters related to the equivalent isotropic displacement parameter of the atom to which it is bonded. The structure determination was achieved using SHELXS  and refinement was done using SHELXL programs included in the SHELX-97 package .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray data collection and refinement

X-ray data collection for 1 was performed at room temperature (293(2) K) with a Xcalibur diffractometer (graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å)) equipped with a Sapphire-II CCD camera as an area detector. The data reduction was done with the CrysAlis RED program . Neither absorption nor extinction corrections were applied. Relevant crystallographic data are shown in  . The structure was solved by direct methods locating most non-hydrogen atoms. It was completed by successive difference Fourier maps. Refinement was anisotropic for non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were calculated at idealized positions with fixed distances, and refined with isotropic displacement parameters related to the equivalent isotropic displacement parameter of the atom to which it is bonded. The structure determination was achieved using SHELXS  and refinement was done using SHELXL programs included in the SHELX-97 package .

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic measurements

Magnetic susceptibility measurements (2.0-300K) were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under an applied magnetic field of 1T at high temperature (T >20K) and 250 G at low temperature (T <20K) to avoid any problem of magnetic saturation. The corrections for the diamagnetism were estimated from Pascal constants .

elements.clean_text:
Potentiometric measurements

Solutions of the metals were standardized according to standard techniques . Solutions were freed of carbon dioxide by Ar bubbling. The standard HCl solution was prepared from Merck standard ampoules. The titrant solution (0.1M solution of Me4N(OH) in 0.5M Me4NCl) was prepared by dissolving Me4N(OH)⋅5H2O (Fluka), and standardized with potassium biphthalate.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The protonation constants of the ligand, oda, were determined through three potentiometric titrations (ca. 150 experimental points each) in the concentration range 10–20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM, covering pH values between 2 and 11. Similarly, hydrolysis constants of Be(II), Al(III) and VO<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> under the conditions of the study were determined by titrations of solutions containing only the cations. Pb(II) hydrolysis was studied in 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M NaNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to avoid PbCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> precipitation. pH values between 2 and those causing precipitation of the corresponding hydroxide, and concentrations between 2 and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM were covered. In our calculations, the model and the values of the stability constants for the hydrolysis of iron(III), proposed by Daniele et al. , have been taken into account. Fe(II) and Sm(III) hydrolysis parameters have been taken from our previously reported values .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The protonation constants of the ligand, oda, were determined through three potentiometric titrations (ca. 150 experimental points each) in the concentration range 10-20mM, covering pH values between 2 and 11. Similarly, hydrolysis constants of Be(II), Al(III) and VO2+ under the conditions of the study were determined by titrations of solutions containing only the cations. Pb(II) hydrolysis was studied in 0.5M NaNO3 to avoid PbCl2 precipitation. pH values between 2 and those causing precipitation of the corresponding hydroxide, and concentrations between 2 and 20mM were covered. In our calculations, the model and the values of the stability constants for the hydrolysis of iron(III), proposed by Daniele et al. , have been taken into account. Fe(II) and Sm(III) hydrolysis parameters have been taken from our previously reported values .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The behavior of oda in the presence of M(II) ions was analyzed through at least three potentiometric titrations (ca. 150 experimental points each) for each metal ion, at concentrations ranging from 0.5 to 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM, and oda:M(II) molar ratios 1:1 to 5:1. For other metal systems, i.e., those containing Sm(III), Fe(III), Al(III) and VO<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, complexation was studied analogously.</ce:para>

For other metal systems, i.e., those containing Sm(III), Fe(III), Al(III) and VO2+, complexation was studied analogously.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In all cases, the solutions were poured into a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL titration cell. After thermal equilibrium was reached, hydrogen ion concentrations were determined in successive readings, each performed after a small incremental addition of standard 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N(OH) solution (carried out with the help of a Crison 2031 piston buret). Electromotive force values were recorded with the help of a Radiometer 85 pH meter, using a glass electrode and a calomel reference electrode. The ionic strength was kept constant throughout the titrations by using solutions containing 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M Me<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NCl and relatively low concentrations of the metal ions. Pre-saturated argon (free of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) was bubbled through the solutions during titrations to eliminate the effect of atmospheric carbon dioxide, and the temperature was kept at 25.0 (±0.1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The cell constants <ce:italic>E°</ce:italic>, and the liquid junction potentials were determined according to the methods of Biedermann and Sillén  and Liberti and Light . Data were analyzed using the HYPERQUAD program , and species distribution diagrams were produced using the HySS program . The fit of the values predicted by the model to the experimental data was estimated on the basis of the parameter <ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>, corresponding to the scaled sum of square differences between predicted and experimental values.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In all cases, the solutions were poured into a 50mL titration cell. After thermal equilibrium was reached, hydrogen ion concentrations were determined in successive readings, each performed after a small incremental addition of standard 0.1M Me4N(OH) solution (carried out with the help of a Crison 2031 piston buret). Electromotive force values were recorded with the help of a Radiometer 85 pH meter, using a glass electrode and a calomel reference electrode. The ionic strength was kept constant throughout the titrations by using solutions containing 0.5M Me4NCl and relatively low concentrations of the metal ions. Pre-saturated argon (free of CO2) was bubbled through the solutions during titrations to eliminate the effect of atmospheric carbon dioxide, and the temperature was kept at 25.0 (±0.1)°C. The cell constants E°, and the liquid junction potentials were determined according to the methods of Biedermann and Sillén  and Liberti and Light . Data were analyzed using the HYPERQUAD program , and species distribution diagrams were produced using the HySS program . The fit of the values predicted by the model to the experimental data was estimated on the basis of the parameter σ, corresponding to the scaled sum of square differences between predicted and experimental values.

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18 for M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cu, Ni, Co, <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10 for Ca, and <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9 for M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn, Mg). In fact, when solids are stored is a desiccator over silica, the TGA showed that, at least, two water molecules are not present anymore. For compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the loss of mass involved a well defined two-steps process (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The first corresponds to crystallization water (12 molecules for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 62<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 12 molecules for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and 3 molecules for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C). The second loss of weight corresponds to coordinated water molecules (6 for complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> – <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> at 202, 220, and 210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively). Hence, they can be formulated as [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>x′H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12 for M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni, Co, and <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>′<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3 for M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Mn). The presence of six coordinated water molecules is also in agreement with the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, described in the next section. Only one process of loss of water can be observed for the other compounds, corresponding to all water molecules. At higher temperatures decomposition of the solid occurs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

The direct reaction of oda in aqueous neutral solution with the stoichiometric amount of M(II) salts (M=Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ca, Mg) and Sm(III) led to the formation of complexes with formula [Sm2M3(oda)6]⋅x H2O (x =18 for M=Cu, Ni, Co, x =10 for Ca, and x =9 for M=Mn, Mg). This composition is supported by the elemental analysis and TGA determinations. Thermal analyses showed mass loss even at low temperatures as 50°C, suggesting the presence of weakly bonded water molecules. This characteristic is especially remarkable in compound 1, and seems to be responsible for the slight disagreement in the elemental analysis results. In fact, when solids are stored is a desiccator over silica, the TGA showed that, at least, two water molecules are not present anymore. For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the loss of mass involved a well defined two-steps process ( ). The first corresponds to crystallization water (12 molecules for 2 at 62°C, 12 molecules for 3 at 80°C, and 3 molecules for 4 at 100°C). The second loss of weight corresponds to coordinated water molecules (6 for complexes 2 - 4 at 202, 220, and 210°C, respectively). Hence, they can be formulated as [Sm2M3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅x'H2O (x'=12 for M=Ni, Co, and x'=3 for M=Mn). The presence of six coordinated water molecules is also in agreement with the structure of 1, described in the next section. Only one process of loss of water can be observed for the other compounds, corresponding to all water molecules. At higher temperatures decomposition of the solid occurs.

<ce:section-title>Description of the structure of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Selected bond lengths and angles for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>, each Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> is tridentately chelated by three oda ligands, forming the building block [Sm(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>. The coordination geometry of the samarium atom can be described as a distorted tricapped trigonal prism. The six carboxylate oxygen atoms form a trigonal prism (Sm–O distance 2.427(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) with three ether oxygen atoms as capping ones at a longer distance, 2.514(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each building block is connected to six Cu atoms <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> single <ce:italic>syn-anti</ce:italic> μ-carboxylato-O,O′ bridges. Sm–Cu distance through this bridge is 5.703<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Copper atoms are six-coordinated. They are surrounded by four carboxylato oxygen atoms (Cu–O distance 1.957(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), which define a perfect equatorial plane and two water molecules at longer distances (Cu–O distance 2.509(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Thus, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> exhibits an elongated octahedral geometry. The coordination polyhedrons of both ions are shown in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Description of the structure of [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅6.5H2O(1)

Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are summarized in  . As shown in  , each Sm3+ is tridentately chelated by three oda ligands, forming the building block [Sm(oda)3]3-. The coordination geometry of the samarium atom can be described as a distorted tricapped trigonal prism. The six carboxylate oxygen atoms form a trigonal prism (Sm-O distance 2.427(3)Å) with three ether oxygen atoms as capping ones at a longer distance, 2.514(4)Å. Each building block is connected to six Cu atoms via single syn-anti μ-carboxylato-O,O' bridges. Sm-Cu distance through this bridge is 5.703Å. Copper atoms are six-coordinated. They are surrounded by four carboxylato oxygen atoms (Cu-O distance 1.957(3)Å), which define a perfect equatorial plane and two water molecules at longer distances (Cu-O distance 2.509(4)Å). Thus, Cu2+ exhibits an elongated octahedral geometry. The coordination polyhedrons of both ions are shown in .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The formation of μ-carboxylato bridges in the three directions yields a 3D network structure. Samarium building blocks create a 2D hexagonal pattern (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>) repeated along the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic> axis. As in the case of analogous structures , hexagonal channels are formed. The diameter of these channels in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is nearly 10.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The formation of μ-carboxylato bridges in the three directions yields a 3D network structure. Samarium building blocks create a 2D hexagonal pattern ( ) repeated along the z axis. As in the case of analogous structures , hexagonal channels are formed. The diameter of these channels in 1 is nearly 10.9Å.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 1-4, in the form of χ MT vs. T (χ MT being the magnetic susceptibility per Sm2M3 unit), are shown in  . At room temperature, all of them present the expected values of χ MT for magnetically isolated paramagnetic ions, i.e., 2.0, 4.1, 10.0 and 13.0 cm3 mol-1 K, respectively. With the exception of 3 (Sm-Co complex), the χ MT values decrease linearly with T up to about 100K. Then, they decrease rapidly to get 0.75, 2.25, 4.6 and 11.2cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1-4, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The Sm(III) ion presents a <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H ground term which is splitt by spin-orbit coupling into six levels, the energy being increased from <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf> to <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">15/2</ce:inf>. The spin-orbit parameter is around 200–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
. So, the first excited state, <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">7/2</ce:inf>, will be significantly populated at room temperature and above. In the free-ion approximation, the expression of the magnetic susceptibility, taking into account the six states arising from <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H, is given in equation A1 (Appendix). From this expression, <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T decreases as T decreases, and tends to a limit value of 0.09<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> K, as <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0. This value can be smaller due to the ligand field effect, which partially splits the <ce:sup loc="pre">6</ce:sup>H<ce:inf loc="post">5/2</ce:inf> ground state. The total multiplet width of such splitting is of a few tens of wavenumbers . However, this effect is not important in describing the magnetic properties of the compounds because of the very low value of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T at low T for the free ion (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>⩽<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.09<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> K).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Sm(III) ion presents a 6H ground term which is splitt by spin-orbit coupling into six levels, the energy being increased from 6H5/2 to 6H15/2. The spin-orbit parameter is around 200-250cm-1 . So, the first excited state, 6H7/2, will be significantly populated at room temperature and above. In the free-ion approximation, the expression of the magnetic susceptibility, taking into account the six states arising from 6H, is given in equation A1 (Appendix). From this expression, χ MT decreases as T decreases, and tends to a limit value of 0.09cm3 mol-1 K, as T →0. This value can be smaller due to the ligand field effect, which partially splits the 6H5/2 ground state. The total multiplet width of such splitting is of a few tens of wavenumbers . However, this effect is not important in describing the magnetic properties of the compounds because of the very low value of χ MT at low T for the free ion (χ M T ⩽0.09cm3mol-1 K).

elements.clean_text: The magnetic behavior under this approach (absence of any magnetic interaction) is depicted in  as dashed lines. Below 100K (50 K for 3) the χ MT values decrease more rapidly, indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the paramagnetic centres. We have used a Weiss constant, θ, with the form of (T-θ) to account for this antiferromagnetic interaction. The corresponding fit in the whole range of temperature is given as solid lines in . The best-fit data for compounds 1-4 are depicted in  . Usual values of λ and g for Sm3+ and the other d-metal ions were obtained. In the case of compound 3, the values of λ=-128cm-1 and A =1.35 (the crystal field parameters) are very close to those observed for other Co(II) complexes .

Neglecting the magnetic interactions SmIII-MII, and using the weak field approximation, an exchange parameter, J', between divalent transition metal ions (MII-MII) can be calculated through Eq. :  (3)  J ' =   3 k θ   zS ( S + 1 )   ,   where z =4 (number of MII nearest neighbors) in all cases. The absolute values of J' decrease from CuII-CuII to MnII-MnII, indicating that the superexchange pathway carboxylato-Sm-carboxylato is operative. In the case that the magnetic interaction were dipolar in nature, the J' values would increase as S is larger.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Chemical speciation in aqueous solution</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The obtained data of protonation constants of the ligand are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl4"></ce:float-anchor>. Results are in line with those previously reported .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">
 shows formation constants of complexes of oda with M(II) and M(III) cations. Stable species were detected for all the studied metal ions. In particular, 1:1 species were always present in the systems. For most +2 cations, ML species (L represents the fully deprotonated form of oda) are predominant. This is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>a. Formation constants of ML species are in line with previously reported data, when available . Only in the case of Pb(II) (b), VO<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, and M<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> cations (c), species containing 2:1 and 3:1 molar ratios (ligand to metal) are important in the speciation. Be(II) exhibits the presence of [Be<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)]<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, a polynuclear species derived from the hydrolytic [Be<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> which is predominant over pH 5. This kind of species have been found in many systems .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Chemical speciation in aqueous solution

The obtained data of protonation constants of the ligand are depicted in  . Results are in line with those previously reported .

  shows formation constants of complexes of oda with M(II) and M(III) cations. Stable species were detected for all the studied metal ions. In particular, 1:1 species were always present in the systems. For most +2 cations, ML species (L represents the fully deprotonated form of oda) are predominant. This is shown in  a. Formation constants of ML species are in line with previously reported data, when available . Only in the case of Pb(II) (b), VO2+, and M3+ cations (c), species containing 2:1 and 3:1 molar ratios (ligand to metal) are important in the speciation. Be(II) exhibits the presence of [Be3(OH)3(oda)]+, a polynuclear species derived from the hydrolytic [Be3(OH)3]3+ which is predominant over pH 5. This kind of species have been found in many systems .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Heterobimetallic species are found (
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl5"></ce:float-anchor>), if Sm, oda and a second metal are mixed in solution. [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> is present for most systems containing M<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, and represents the predominant species in solution (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>). It can be derived from the neutral less soluble species [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>], isolated at solid state. This neutral species was not detected in solution. Hydroxide groups in the hydroxylated species are probably coordinated to M, taking into account the presence of coordinated water into the crystal structure. For Be(II), Ca(II), Mg(II), Mn(II), Fe(II), Pb(II), and Al(III), [SmM(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> is also detected. This species, containing only one OH<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> group per mol, is predominant in the case of Ca(II) and Mg(II). Be(II) also forms an hydroxylated species, [SmBeL<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, which is predominant in the systems, specially at pH values higher than 7.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Heterobimetallic species are found ( ), if Sm, oda and a second metal are mixed in solution. [Sm2M3(oda)6(OH)3]3- is present for most systems containing M2+ cations, and represents the predominant species in solution ( ). It can be derived from the neutral less soluble species [Sm2M3(oda)6(H2O)6], isolated at solid state. This neutral species was not detected in solution. Hydroxide groups in the hydroxylated species are probably coordinated to M, taking into account the presence of coordinated water into the crystal structure. For Be(II), Ca(II), Mg(II), Mn(II), Fe(II), Pb(II), and Al(III), [SmM(oda)3(OH)]2- is also detected. This species, containing only one OH- group per mol, is predominant in the case of Ca(II) and Mg(II). Be(II) also forms an hydroxylated species, [SmBeL3(OH)2]3-, which is predominant in the systems, specially at pH values higher than 7.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Trivalent cations, Fe(III) and Al(III), like most +2 cations, predominate as a 2:3:6 species, but in this case with a higher degree of deprotonation. [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Fe<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, and [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Al<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> are the predominant species.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Trivalent cations, Fe(III) and Al(III), like most +2 cations, predominate as a 2:3:6 species, but in this case with a higher degree of deprotonation. [Sm2Fe3(oda)6(OH)6]3-, and [Sm2Al3(oda)6(OH)5]2- are the predominant species.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Concluding remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">2,2′-Oxydiacetate has proved to bridge Sm(III) and different di and trivalent cations. The formation of species containing [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] units has been found at solid state, and, for the first time, in solution. The structure of the solid compound [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O follows those found for Cu(II) and other lanthanide ions. The presence of large channels in the 3D array was also found. Our results of the potentiometric experiments suggest that these species are also present in solution, probably containing this stable and particular arrangement. This result opens the possibility to assay the compounds in many and new applications.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Concluding remarks

2,2'-Oxydiacetate has proved to bridge Sm(III) and different di and trivalent cations. The formation of species containing [Sm2M3] units has been found at solid state, and, for the first time, in solution. The structure of the solid compound [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅6.5H2O follows those found for Cu(II) and other lanthanide ions. The presence of large channels in the 3D array was also found. Our results of the potentiometric experiments suggest that these species are also present in solution, probably containing this stable and particular arrangement. This result opens the possibility to assay the compounds in many and new applications.

Supplementary data

Showing the coordination polyhedrons of Sm3+ and Cu2+ ions in 1. Crystallographic data for structural analysis of compound 1 have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic data centre, CCDC 275623. Copies of this information may be obtained free of charge from the Director CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2-1EZ, UK (fax: + 44-1223-336033, e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk). Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.molstruc.2006.03.103.

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water. 2,2′-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in another 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear blue solution was obtained. After a few minutes a microcrystalline pale blue solid was obtained, and separated by filtration, washed with water (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and dried with acetone (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and diethylether (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). The mother liquour was allowed to evaporate slowly for 4–5 days in order to obtain suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction. Yield 60–70%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 17.9; H, 3.8. Found: C, 19.8; H, 4.2%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1605, 1439, and 1124<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 19.6% in the range 50–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.2%. Decomposition point, 216<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water. 2,2′-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in another 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear green solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for 4–5 days. A pale green solid was filtered, washed with water (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), and dried with acetone (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and diethylether (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Yield 35–40%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>Ni<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 18.1; H, 3.8. Found: C, 18.0; H, 4.0%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1618, 1438, and 1125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.4% in the range 50–220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.3%. Decomposition point, 296<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This compound was obtained as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, starting from Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). A microcrystalline pink solid was collected after 4–5 days. Yield 40–45%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">48</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 18.1; H, 3.8. Found: C, 17.9; H, 4.1%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1608, 1438, and 1125<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.5% in the range 50–160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.4%. Decomposition point, 237<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">This compound was obtained as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, starting from Mn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Cubic pale yellow crystals were collected after 4–5 days. Yield 40–45%. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">42</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">39</ce:inf>Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 20.3; H, 3.0. Found: C, 20.2; H, 3.1%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1608, 1438, and 1120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Synthesis of the complexes

Synthesis of [Sm2 Cu3(oda)6]⋅18H2O(1)

Cu(NO3)2 ⋅3H2O (0.36g, 1.5mmol) and Sm(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.0mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2'-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40g, 3.0mmol) was dissolved in another 10mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear blue solution was obtained. After a few minutes a microcrystalline pale blue solid was obtained, and separated by filtration, washed with water (3×2mL), and dried with acetone (2×2mL) and diethylether (3×2mL). The mother liquour was allowed to evaporate slowly for 4-5 days in order to obtain suitable crystals for X-ray diffraction. Yield 60-70%. Anal. Calc. for C24H60O48Cu3Sm2: C, 17.9; H, 3.8. Found: C, 19.8; H, 4.2%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1605, 1439, and 1124cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 19.6% in the range 50-100°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.2%. Decomposition point, 216°C.

Synthesis of [Sm2Ni3 (oda)6]⋅18H2O(2)

Ni(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.5mmol) and Sm(NO3)3 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.0mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2'-Oxydiacetic acid (0.40g, 3.0mmol) was dissolved in another 10mL water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear green solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature for 4-5 days. A pale green solid was filtered, washed with water (3×2mL), and dried with acetone (2×2mL) and diethylether (3×2mL). Yield 35-40%. Anal. Calc. for C24H60O48Ni3Sm2: C, 18.1; H, 3.8. Found: C, 18.0; H, 4.0%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1618, 1438, and 1125cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.4% in the range 50-220°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.3%. Decomposition point, 296°C.

Synthesis of [Sm2 Co3(oda)6]⋅18H2O(3)

This compound was obtained as 2, starting from Co(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.44g, 1.5mmol). A microcrystalline pink solid was collected after 4-5 days. Yield 40-45%. Anal. Calc. for C24H60O48Co3Sm2: C, 18.1; H, 3.8. Found: C, 17.9; H, 4.1%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1608, 1438, and 1125cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 20.5% in the range 50-160°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 20.4%. Decomposition point, 237°C.

Synthesis of [Sm2 Mn3(oda)6]⋅9H2O(4)

This compound was obtained as 2, starting from Mn(NO3)2 ⋅4H2O (0.38g, 1.5mmol). Cubic pale yellow crystals were collected after 4-5 days. Yield 40-45%. Anal. Calc. for C24H42O39Mn3Sm2: C, 20.3; H, 3.0. Found: C, 20.2; H, 3.1%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1608, 1438, and 1120cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 11.5% in the range 50-240°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 11.6%. Decomposition point, 310°C.

Synthesis of [Sm2 Ca3(oda)6]⋅10H2O(5)

Pale yellow crystals of this compound were obtained as 2, starting from CaCl2 ⋅2H2O (0.22g, 1.5mmol). Yield 15-25%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Sm2: C, 20.7; H, 3.2. Found: C, 20.8; H, 3.2%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1616, 1438, and 1124cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 12.8% in the range 160-220°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 12.9%. Decomposition point, 210°C.

Synthesis of [Sm2 Mg3(oda)6] ⋅9H2O(6)

Pale yellow crystals of this compound were obtained as 2, starting from MgCl2 ⋅6H2O (0.31g, 1.5mmol). Yield 15-25%. Anal. Calc. for C24H42O39Mg3Sm2: C, 21.7; H, 3.2. Found: C, 22.2; H, 4.6%. IR peaks associated to the oda ligand appear at: 1621, 1436, and 1122cm-1. The TGA diagram shows a weight loss of 11.6% in the range 80-160°C which corresponds to the loss of all water molecules, calc. 12.2%. Decomposition point, 165°C.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic measurements

Magnetic susceptibility measurements (2.0-300K) were carried out with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer under an applied magnetic field of 1T at high temperature (T >20K) and 250 G at low temperature (T <20K) to avoid any problem of magnetic saturation. The corrections for the diamagnetism were estimated from Pascal constants .

Results and discussion

Synthesis and characterization

The direct reaction of oda in aqueous neutral solution with the stoichiometric amount of M(II) salts (M=Cu, Ni, Co, Mn, Ca, Mg) and Sm(III) led to the formation of complexes with formula [Sm2M3(oda)6]⋅x H2O (x =18 for M=Cu, Ni, Co, x =10 for Ca, and x =9 for M=Mn, Mg). This composition is supported by the elemental analysis and TGA determinations. Thermal analyses showed mass loss even at low temperatures as 50°C, suggesting the presence of weakly bonded water molecules. This characteristic is especially remarkable in compound 1, and seems to be responsible for the slight disagreement in the elemental analysis results. In fact, when solids are stored is a desiccator over silica, the TGA showed that, at least, two water molecules are not present anymore. For compounds 2, 3, and 4, the loss of mass involved a well defined two-steps process ( ). The first corresponds to crystallization water (12 molecules for 2 at 62°C, 12 molecules for 3 at 80°C, and 3 molecules for 4 at 100°C). The second loss of weight corresponds to coordinated water molecules (6 for complexes 2 - 4 at 202, 220, and 210°C, respectively). Hence, they can be formulated as [Sm2M3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅x'H2O (x'=12 for M=Ni, Co, and x'=3 for M=Mn). The presence of six coordinated water molecules is also in agreement with the structure of 1, described in the next section. Only one process of loss of water can be observed for the other compounds, corresponding to all water molecules. At higher temperatures decomposition of the solid occurs.

Description of the structure of [Sm2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6]⋅6.5H2O(1)

Selected bond lengths and angles for 1 are summarized in  . As shown in  , each Sm3+ is tridentately chelated by three oda ligands, forming the building block [Sm(oda)3]3-. The coordination geometry of the samarium atom can be described as a distorted tricapped trigonal prism. The six carboxylate oxygen atoms form a trigonal prism (Sm-O distance 2.427(3)Å) with three ether oxygen atoms as capping ones at a longer distance, 2.514(4)Å. Each building block is connected to six Cu atoms via single syn-anti μ-carboxylato-O,O' bridges. Sm-Cu distance through this bridge is 5.703Å. Copper atoms are six-coordinated. They are surrounded by four carboxylato oxygen atoms (Cu-O distance 1.957(3)Å), which define a perfect equatorial plane and two water molecules at longer distances (Cu-O distance 2.509(4)Å). Thus, Cu2+ exhibits an elongated octahedral geometry. The coordination polyhedrons of both ions are shown in .

The formation of μ-carboxylato bridges in the three directions yields a 3D network structure. Samarium building blocks create a 2D hexagonal pattern ( ) repeated along the z axis. As in the case of analogous structures , hexagonal channels are formed. The diameter of these channels in 1 is nearly 10.9Å.

Magnetic properties

The magnetic properties of compounds 1-4, in the form of χ MT vs. T (χ MT being the magnetic susceptibility per Sm2M3 unit), are shown in  . At room temperature, all of them present the expected values of χ MT for magnetically isolated paramagnetic ions, i.e., 2.0, 4.1, 10.0 and 13.0 cm3 mol-1 K, respectively. With the exception of 3 (Sm-Co complex), the χ MT values decrease linearly with T up to about 100K. Then, they decrease rapidly to get 0.75, 2.25, 4.6 and 11.2cm3 mol-1 K at 2K for 1-4, respectively.

The Sm(III) ion presents a 6H ground term which is splitt by spin-orbit coupling into six levels, the energy being increased from 6H5/2 to 6H15/2. The spin-orbit parameter is around 200-250cm-1 . So, the first excited state, 6H7/2, will be significantly populated at room temperature and above. In the free-ion approximation, the expression of the magnetic susceptibility, taking into account the six states arising from 6H, is given in equation A1 (Appendix). From this expression, χ MT decreases as T decreases, and tends to a limit value of 0.09cm3 mol-1 K, as T →0. This value can be smaller due to the ligand field effect, which partially splits the 6H5/2 ground state. The total multiplet width of such splitting is of a few tens of wavenumbers . However, this effect is not important in describing the magnetic properties of the compounds because of the very low value of χ MT at low T for the free ion (χ M T ⩽0.09cm3mol-1 K).

The magnetic behavior under this approach (absence of any magnetic interaction) is depicted in  as dashed lines. Below 100K (50 K for 3) the χ MT values decrease more rapidly, indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the paramagnetic centres. We have used a Weiss constant, θ, with the form of (T-θ) to account for this antiferromagnetic interaction. The corresponding fit in the whole range of temperature is given as solid lines in . The best-fit data for compounds 1-4 are depicted in  . Usual values of λ and g for Sm3+ and the other d-metal ions were obtained. In the case of compound 3, the values of λ=-128cm-1 and A =1.35 (the crystal field parameters) are very close to those observed for other Co(II) complexes .

Table 3. Best fit data on χ MT values for compounds 1 – 4

| Compound | λ(Sm3+) /cm−1 | gM  | −θ/K | −J′/cm−1[^b] |
|----------|--------------|-----|------|-------------|
| 1        | 221.2        | 2.08| 2.13 | 1.48        |
| 2        | 223.6        | 2.12| 1.06 | 0.28        |
| 3        | 220.0[^a]    | 0.21| 0.03 |             |
| 4        | 230.3        | 2.0 | 0.37 | 0.02        |

[^a]: The analysis of the Co(II) ion was done taking into account the spin-orbit coupling, λ, in Oh symmetry. The data obtained in this way were: λCo(II) =−128cm−1 and A =1.35 (see text).
[^b]: Calculated from the expression J′=3kθ/ZS(S+1), with Z =4.

<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (a), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (b), <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (c) and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (d): (o) experimental data; (- - -) best fit curve considering no magnetic interaction; (—-) best fit curve considering antiferromagnetic interaction (see text).</ce:simple-para>
